intro: Oedera oppositifolia, commonly known as the opposite-leafed wood sorrel, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It features alternate, heart-shaped leaves with a distinctive veining pattern that is characteristic of the Oxalidaceae family. The plant produces small, yellow flowers with five petals, typically blooming in early spring. Its roots are fibrous and often used in traditional medicine for their purported health benefits. Oedera oppositifolia thrives in moist, shady environments and is often found in woodland areas and along stream banks.
